title: 105_hr3460
content: The governing international fishery agreement with Latvia and the reauthorization of the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Convention Act of 1995 are approved and will enter into force upon enactment of this Act. The Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Convention Act of 1995 is amended for fiscal years through 2001. Miscellaneous technical amendments are made, including changes to sections 207(e), 209(c), and 210(6). A new report requirement is added as section 212. The Secretary must annually report to Congress on the activities of various fisheries-related councils and committees. Additionally, a new section is added regarding quota allocation practices within the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization. The Secretary of Commerce, in collaboration with the Secretary of State, is tasked with establishing a new quota allocation practice under the Convention that is predictable, transparent, and provides fishing opportunities for all members. This practice must also align with the Straddling Fish Stocks Agreement. Annual reports must include negotiation results, barriers to implementation, and recommendations for any necessary legislation. The United Nations Agreement for the Implementation of the Provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea of 10 December 1982 Relating to the Conservation and Management of Straddling Fish Stocks and Highly Migratory Fish Stocks is referred to as the Agreement. The Atlantic Tunas Convention Act of 1975 is being reauthorized. The Atlantic Tunas Convention Act of 1975 is amended for fiscal years 1998, 1999, 2000, and 2001. Miscellaneous technical amendments are made to sections of the Act, including redesignating paragraphs and updating terminology. The Atlantic Tunas Convention Act of 1975 is amended by redesignating sections, updating terminology, and changing references from "Magnuson Fishery" to "Magnuson-Stevens Fishery." Additionally, a section of the Act from 1980 is amended by adding "of 1975" after "Act." SEC. 4. AUTHORITY OF STATES OF WASHINGTON, OREGON, AND CALIFORNIA TO MANAGE DUNGENESS CRAB FISHERY. States of Washington, Oregon, and California have the authority to enforce State laws for Dungeness crab fisheries in the exclusive economic zone, regardless of any fishery management plan under the Magnuson-Stevens Act. State laws must apply equally to vessels in the exclusive economic zone and state waters. The States of Washington, Oregon, and California have the authority to enforce State laws for Dungeness crab fisheries in the exclusive economic zone. These laws may not be enforced against vessels legally fishing in the exclusive economic zone adjacent to the State and not registered under the State's laws, except for laws regulating landings. Vessels must have a State permit or treaty right to harvest or process Dungeness crab in the exclusive economic zone adjacent to these States. The States of Washington, Oregon, and California have the authority to regulate Dungeness crab fisheries in the exclusive economic zone, except with a permit or tribal treaty rights. This authority will expire once a fishery management plan is in place under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. Repeal of Section 112(d) of Public Law 104-297 (16 U.S.C. 1856 note) and application of definitions from the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act (16 U.S.C. 1802) to this section. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on August 3, 1998.
